bioghist.p: John Thurloe (1616-1668) was a secretary to the council of state of the Commonwealth of Great Britain under Oliver Cromwell. He was given charge of the intelligence department in 1653, which included foreign and domestic espionage, and the post office in 1655. Through the post office Thurloe was able to intercept information of plots against the government. He entered Parliament in 1654, and supported the succession of Richard Cromwell in 1658. He was deprived of office after the fall of the Protectorate, and was arrested for high treason after the Restoration in 1660. He was not tried, and was released on the condition that his services be available to the Restoration government.

scopecontent.p: This collection of five volumes contains copies of letters received by John Thurloe and important state papers and news letters. The volumes correspond to six of Thurloe's original volumes (which appear to have numbered at least 66) and cover the years 1654 to 1659. The letters discuss some of the most important events of the period, including the plot to assassinate Cromwell, naval affairs, and Cromwell's death in 1658 and the succession of his son Richard as Lord Protector. The original volumes are in the holdings of the Bodleian Library and the British Museum.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
